story:
On November 5th 2020 my father, David Timothy Stott died of a brain tumour aged 75 which was all so sudden in the short space of 9 weeks.

Not only was he the best most perfect Dad I could ever wish for, he was my best friend, my hero, the best husband in the World to my Mum, the best grandfather anyone could wish for to my children Lucy and Lila, an amazing brother & brother in law to my aunties and uncles, and the best Uncle to all of his nieces and nephews.

One of the things at the top of my Dad's list to do, was to skydive but he never got the opportunity. Therefore I thought what could be a more fitting way than to do it for him at the same time as saying a big thank you to Macmillan who provided the most amazing support and care for both Dad and Mum.

Therefore this one is for you Dad. My charity tandem Skydive, from between 10,000ft and 15,000ft will take place in April 2021 at Peterlee (County Durham).

story:
Hello. I'm Myrna. 

I've enjoyed painting since I was about 12. Some time ago!

More recently, in lockdown, I've been painting greetings cards for friends from their favourite photos of their furry loved ones - and I'm loving it! 

Then their friends started asking me if I would paint their pets and have been offering to pay. 

That's when I decided it would be nice to see if we can all raise some money for a charity that's all about caring.

We all win if you take me up on this offer...

  • You get a lovely watercolour rendition of your, or your friend's, favourite little pal - either as a greeting card or ready to be framed - or both!
  • I get to paint more pictures, enjoying the challenge of capturing their characters in watercolour.
  • And Macmillan gets more support for the brilliant work they do.

Macmillan give people with cancer so much support. If you’re diagnosed, they are there for you.  But without your help they can’t support everyone who needs them.

I look forward to hearing from you.

Each participant will undertake 5km, either walking, running or cycling, to help us get to the total distance. Thanks!

eventName: Which?'s Walk, Run and Cycle for Sarah
story:
Thanks for visiting our team fundraising page. We work for Which? and we are fundraising for the British Heart Foundation in memory of our friend and colleague Sarah Price, who passed away suddenly last year at the age of 39. Sarah was a wonderful person; she excelled in her job but was also a committed team-player, going to great lengths to help her team members day-in, day-out. She was a brilliant friend: funny and kind, someone who always made time for everyone she encountered.

Sarah was a close friend and colleague of mine, she was in my team and we started on the same day at Which, we sat next to each other at the office.. her passing came to a massive shock to me and still greatly saddened by it... I think of her daily. 

Sarah was a big fan of Welsh rugby and so we are planning to run, walk or cycle a combined distance that will stretch from our Bristol office, where Sarah worked, to the Principality Stadium in Cardiff and back again, which is around 86 miles in total. We plan to do this over the weekend of 27 - 28 February 2021, being the weekend closest to both St. David's Day and Sarah's 5-year anniversary since she started at Which?.Each participant will undertake 5km, either walking, running or cycling, to help us get to the total distance. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to donations that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help us hit our target. Thanks!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
This is going to be hard.

Anyone who knows me knows I LOVE anything sweet. I cannot resist a biscuit, a bit of chocolate or a sweetie.  I am guilty of eating something sweet every day. I would go as far as to say I’m addicted to the sweet stuff.  I have never tried to give it up completely for any length of time. 

The last time I really ‘dug deep’ and went out of my comfort zone was to abseil  off the Forth Bridge. I kid you not... giving up everything sweet for a month is  going to be just as challenging, only in a quieter, more prolonged way.

So this is it. I am going to give it my very best because this is the best reason to... The British Heart Foundation.  This an amazing charity who aim to raise money to help fund research into such a devastating disease. Many of you know this is a cause very close to my heart. 

Please don’t feel obligated to donate; I am trying to do this as much as a personal challenge to myself rather than to raise money. But if you would like to donate to The British Heart Foundation, A HUGE THANK YOU.

No sweeties or chocolate for a month?! Wish me luck!!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The Covid-19 pandemic is the biggest challenge The British heart foundation has faced in its 60 year history. The pandemic forced a devastating decision to be made, to cut the 2020 research budget in half. Fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help keep up the pace of progress. Despite everything happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the worlds biggest killers. 💔 for the sake of mums, dads, brothers, sisters, grandparents and friends - we can’t drop the ball now. 

Please help me do this, on a personal level and the reason I felt inspired to take part this year was due to my cousin Lauren. She was born with ventricular septal defect commonly known as a hole in the heart. Along with other complications such as pulmonary atresia,  Lauren has faced many risky and life threatening surgery’s. One in which she will undertake in a matter of weeks. Imagine facing open heart surgery during a pandemic! It feels particularly difficult as we, along with many other family’s facing such surgery’s cannot physically support our loved ones. It will be a months before I can see her and give her a cuddle. 💔 now that is heart breaking! 

The man entrusted in keeping Lauren’s heart safe during this surgery is professor massimo Caputo. With the financial support from the British heart foundation, he has been able to change the lives of not only Lauren but babies and children born with congenital heart disease. His on going research and dedication to his work is improving the way small babies and children and operated on with higher success rates and long term prognosis improving.

So all I have to do it give up sweets, chocolate and fizzy drinks for a month.....that’s it 🤷🏼‍♀️ Hoping that some of you will make a donation to the British heart foundation through me.  Compared to what Lauren and many others will be facing this year my half of the deal doesn’t seem so bad. What’s a Mars bar or a can of coke....it’s a chance....or a new valve.....it’s a heartbeat....it’s a life   ❤️ 

Please help me help those who are mending and preventing broken hearts ❤️ Thank you 😊 

💕I dedicate this fundraiser to Lauren, who I can’t see and be with right now, but know we are cheering you on from a distance. You have faced your surgery’s with such courage and strength and this time will be the same. We are all so proud and send so much love and strength to you. Until we are together again (hopefully very soon) lots of love 💕 

“Be strong, be fearless, be beautiful. And believe that anything is possible when you have the right people there to support you”    Misty Copeland.

story:
Thanks to the kindness of you all, Dave and I were recently able to complete our original target of £2,500 to Name A Puppy "Bonzo". This means such a lot to us both, particularly in the contect of the recent and sudden death of Dave's beloved guide dog, Chad.

We are now hoping to raise another £2,500 for another guide dog puppy, "Herbert".

Dave:

We all know that dogs are pretty amazing creatures, talented, often funny, sometimes serious but overall gifted with their own individuality. Now, just imagine that you are totally blind and need the support and expertise of one of these precious animals to lead you across the mouth of Oxford Street. Perhaps you might need to use the underground to get to work or travel across the Pennines to see your Gran. Now imagine that you are achieving all of this with the support of a brilliant four-legged mobility operative.

Over the last 40+ years, I’ve been lucky enough to be partnered with these incredible creatures. The sense of weaving through the underground or walking along the street without fear is just mind-blowing, and all because this four-legged, fur-covered fabulousness is right by your side, keeping you safe and on track. I’ve had this privilege for over half my life and am passionate that other people in a similar boat to me receive the same care, love and attention that I’ve received by one of the finest charities active on the planet today.

For other people to enjoy the same love, attention and support I’ve
received, please give generously to the Herbert name-a-puppy appeal. Not only would you be giving a few of your coppers to a brilliant charity, you would be allowing another vision impaired person or child to take their first steps in the world with a friendship that only grows from strength to strength and really does change a life. I know, because mine was.

Thank you for your faultless ongoing support and I know that, between us all, we can pull together to allow someone else to have a slice of the good stuff with Wendy, Hevan, Melthorne or, best of all, Bonzo.

John:

Having spent time with Dave, it has become so clear to me what an amazing blessing his dog, Chad is to him. Having written our song "Together We Shine" to raise awareness for Guide Dogs UK, we both thought it would be wonderful if we could help someone else receive the same love and support that Chad gives to Dave. Working with the existing Guide Dogs UK "Name A Puppy" scheme, which gives support to puppies in their Guide Dog training, we are hoping to raise enough money to train a guide dog, and name it "Herbert".

With much love,

John and Dave

story:
New in Wales for this year’s Great Daffodil Appeal, a fantastic St David’s Day fundraising activity! 

Get together virtually with family, friends, colleagues or go it alone and take on our quiz ‘How Welsh are you anyway?’ hosted by the lovely Amy Dowden, professional dancer and star of BBC's Strictly Come Dancing. 

The ultimate quiz to test if your Welsh knowledge or learn something you didn’t know! 

Along with your quiz you’ll receive a tidy pack of extra activities including:
Welsh Crossword & Wordsearch
Colour in Daffodil to display in your window
Welsh cake recipe
Welsh cocktail recipes

**Please email Walesfundraising@mariecurie.org.uk to receive your fundraising pack** 

The Great Daffodil Appeal 2021 means more to us than ever. Our Nurses and Information and Support Team have been working throughout the pandemic providing care and support for dying people and their loved ones. At the same time, we’ve been unable to fundraise as normal. So just as our care is needed more than ever, we urgently need your support to help us carry on our vital work.

We know how proud we are in Wales to wear our daffodils on 1st March and this year will be no different. We invite you to celebrate St David’s Day with Marie Curie Cymru.   

This year, on the 23rd March 2021 we will also be asking you to wear your daffodil once more to join Marie Curie as we unite the nation to create a day of reflection where communities can remember, grieve and celebrate the lives of everyone who has died during lockdown. Over two million people have been bereaved since the UK lockdown began, whether as a result of coronavirus or another cause. We need a time together to reflect on our collective sense of loss, and to remember and celebrate the lives of the people who’ve died, as we begin to heal from the trauma of this national crisis. The day to reflect, grieve and remember will coincide with the one-year anniversary of lockdown.

We really hope that you will join us to mark these special occasions. No matter how you choose to fundraise for us this year, it means the world to us and we promise to support you every step of the way.

Thank you

story:
Dad and mum were a very sociable couple - active and busy - joiners of different clubs but especially golf !  Once they joined they got involved and made a contribution to supporting and developing the clubs. In doing so they met so many good people. In common was their love to have a good time, enjoy the friendships built and the parties and trips all over the world that resulted. 

After mum died of stomach cancer, Dad continued to be busy making new friends as well as learning how to work the washing machine !  As a family we have got to know many of you and are grateful for all the joy you brought to Dad's life without mum. 

Dad was a real family man and created lots of celebrations for us all to get together with his grandchildren and now his great grand daughter.   We are blessed with so many happy loving memories as a family. 

Sadly his life story ended in Ninewells with Covid but in the most peaceful way with attentive and supportive staff, despite the months and months they have been doing this. Our heartfelt thanks to all of them. Val was with him so he was not alone and for this we will be forever grateful. 

Marie Curie as a charity was close to Dad's heart - they had supported both mum and himself when mum was ill and he had continued to support them after her death.  As a family we would like to continue to honour this connection in his memory.

We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story: I'm donning my walking boots in March and doing 10,000 steps every day to raise money for the amazing Marie Curie Nurses. They have continued to give their incredible care all throughout the COVID pandemic, to people who are sadly at the end of their lives. This means that people have been cared for at home in line with their wishes, and also that family members have had the chance to get some much needed rest. It costs £20 an hour for a Marie Curie Nurse to care for someone at home, and I'm raising £360 to pay for 2 nights of care for patients and families who desperately need it. I'm so grateful for every donation, no matter how small. Thank you for all your support.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
The RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown. Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives has not stopped. 

Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds has been limited.  The average lifeboat station in the North West costs £136,000 a year to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income due to the Coronavirus. We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running.  

We will always be there to keep you and your loved ones safe.  Our mission is there will be no preventable deaths on the North West coast. Please help us fulfil that mission.

To find out more about the RNLI in New Brighton, including the station, shouts and lifeboat please visit https://rnli.org/find-my-nearest/lifeboat-stations/new-brighton-lifeboat-station

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
You can use this JustGiving Page to support anybody who is taking part in the Cornwall RNLI virtual challenge 2021 but who does not have their own JustGiving Page. Any donations given will help support the RNLI's volunteer crews in saving lives around our coast. 

The Challenge is to complete a Run, Walk, Cycle, or Swim over the period between 1st February to 31st March. The distance can be between any two or more Cornish Lifeboat Stations, picking the distance that best suits and it can be carried out anywhere, be that a garden, park, swimming pool or even a treadmill.

There are a total of 13 RNLI lifeboat stations around the coast of Cornwall, from Bude to Looe with the total overall distance is 228 miles. 

Bude to Port Isaac = 30 miles

Port Isaac to Rock = 9 miles

Rock to Padstow 17 miles

Padstow to Newquay = 15 miles

Newquay to St Agnes = 13 miles

St Agnes to St Ives = 21 miles

St Ives to Sennen = 17 miles

Sennen to Penlee = 8 miles

Penlee to Lizard = 25 miles

Lizard to Falmouth = 21 miles

Falmouth to Fowey = 33 miles

Fowey to Looe = 19 miles

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
The nearest Lifeboat Station to the Midlands might be over 100 miles away, but with 87% of residents of the Midlands visiting the coast each year, you don't have to live by the sea to support the RNLI.

The RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown.

Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives has not stopped.

Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds has been limited.

The coasts of Wales and North West England are popular tourist destinations for millions of holidaymakers from the Midlands and we want to keep those coasts a safe place for everyone to visit.

The average lifeboat station in Wales, North West England and Isle of Man costs £159,000 a year to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income due to the Coronavirus.

We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running.

When you and your loved ones visit the coast, we will always be there to keep you safe, on our watch, there will be no preventable deaths on British coasts.

Please help us fulfil that mission by making a donation to our fundraising page, no matter how big or small.

Thank you.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
We're walking 20,000km from St Albans (UK) to Cox's Bazar (Bangladesh), visiting Oxfam projects along the way. 

We'll see the challenges communities face from conflict, to Covid-19 to the impact of the climate emergency and how Oxfam is responding to support communities to thrive, not just survive. 

With your support, Oxfam can continue its life-saving work, it can continue to put together packages of food, give farming support, set up foodbanks, support education for women and girls, and provide cash to buy essentials.

For each £15 we raise, we could help more women to understand their rights, challenge discrimination and to take up leadership roles within their local communities.

For each £35, we could help families access emergency food supplies. 

£45 could provide one of our new handwashing stations to enable frequent handwashing and disease prevention.

With your support, communities can come together to help each other.

I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.
